article_text:
Starbucks has announced that it is temporarily closing all stores in Russia amid the Ukraine crisis.

In a letter released on Tuesday (March 8th), CEO Kevin Johnson said that the coffee chain â€œcondemns the horrific attacks on Ukraine by Russiaâ€ and has therefore decided to â€œsuspend all business activity in Russiaâ€.

This includes â€œpausing store operationsâ€ and ceasing â€œshipment of all Starbucks productsâ€ in the country.

How many Starbucks stores are there in Russia? Read on to find outâ€¦

Photo by Sergei Mikhailichenko/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images

Number of Starbucks stores in Russia

In a letter to Starbucks partners on March 4th 2022, CEO Kevin Johnson revealed that there are currently 130 Starbucks branches in Russia.

However, these are not known as â€˜cafÃ©sâ€™, they are stores that sell Starbucks products and take away items and have little sitting.

All of these outlets are owned and operated by a licensed partner and there are 2,000 green apron partners across Russia.

Every one of these branches will be temporarily closed whilst Russia continues to attack Ukraine.

This content could not be loaded Just today in Russia:



â€“ @McDonalds closing 850 restaurants

â€“ @CocaCola suspends its business

â€“ @PepsiCo suspends sale of its brands

â€“ @Starbucks suspends business

â€“ @amazon stops accepting new AWS customers

â€“ @UMG suspends operations

â€“ @bumble discontinues operations â€” Andrew Arenge (@MrArenge) March 9, 2022

Starbucks offers support to partners

Kevin Johnson revealed that Starbucks will help those who will be affected by the closures.

â€œWe will provide support to the nearly 2,000 partners in Russia who depend on Starbucks for their livelihood,â€ he said.

â€œThrough this dynamic situation, we will continue to make decisions that are true to our mission and values and communicate with transparency.â€

In an earlier letter, he also said: â€œI want to express deep care for the livelihoods of our 2,000 green apron partners in Russia.â€

â€œLike you, my heart is heavy â€“ and I want you to know that no matter what, we stand together, as partners,â€ he continued.

However, at the time of writing this itâ€™s unclear how Starbucks will support the partners who have been forced to close their branches.

Coffee chain provides aid to Ukraine

Prior to the closure of all Starbucks stories in Russia, the coffee chain announced that it would provide financial aid to Ukraine in three ways.

Starbucks pledged to donate any royalties they receive from business operations in Russia to â€œhumanitarian relief efforts for Ukraineâ€.

They also announced that The Starbucks Foundation has contributed â€œ$500,000 to World Central Kitchen and the Red Cross for humanitarian relief efforts for Ukraineâ€.

Their EMEA business will also â€œcontinue to work in the market to support people in need through additional financial contributions and serviceâ€.

article_text:
The windows of this bakery weren't shattered by looters, but by Russian bombing. It remains open.

Mike Jason retired from the U.S. Army as a Colonel and went on to become a professor, historian, author, and speech writer. In recent years, heâ€™s been notable both for his cogent explanation of U.S. failings during the occupation of Afghanistan, and his vocal defense of Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman during Donald Trumpâ€™s first impeachment. Since this has been a day for looking at analysis of the situation in Ukraine and in Russia, this seems like a good time to bring up Jasonâ€™s look the other end of the cost of the warâ€”what it will cost in the United States?

To start with, that costs is definitely worth it.

â€œThe world, with American leadership, Is trying to choke off an aggressive fascist state without starting WWIII. As a result, gas prices are going to go up. Hell, the price of everything is going to go up.â€

On the surface, this tradeoff seems almost superficial. Bring down an aggressive fascist state without directly engaging the U.S. military, and while doing everything possible to prevent the war from expanding outside itâ€™s current area of conflict? It seems like an easy deal. However, as Jason points out, just because itâ€™s a better deal than an actual shooting war between NATO and Russia, doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s a get-out-of-pain free card. For many people, the increases in costs will hit hard. There are millions of people out there who are always on the brink when it comes to their finances. There are also people out there who might have just made a decisionâ€”like buying a new truckâ€”which seemed completely reasonable without factoring in a war they didnâ€™t know was coming.

â€œFirst, from my old unit pep talks: â€˜don't be an asshole.â€™ Now is not the time to make your dig about someone's pick up truck choice or to be smug about your Tesla. Everything will cost more for everyone. Remember we are all in this together.â€

For better than a decade, oil prices have been remarkably low. After peaking around 2008, at a point when it looked like $100 a barrel and up was the indefinite future, the rapid spread of fracking across the U.S. and around the world brought on a super abundance; a world where oil production has been limited by demand rather than production. In Cheap Oil World, some of the dependencies and decisions that were made seemed entirely reasonable (so long, of course, as the environment, and specifically the critical damage to the climate, werenâ€™t considered).

But now weâ€™re seeing the price of cheap oil and cheap natural gas. And if weâ€™re not careful, weâ€™ll pay for it in widening divisions in the U.S.
